It is a public law school, with more than 500 students attending and working toward a [[Juris Doctor]] or [[Master of Laws|Master of Studies in Law]].<ref name="MSL">{{cite web | url = http://www.colorado.edu/law/academics/degrees/msl-degree-program | title = MSL Degree Program | publisher = University of Colorado | access-date = June 3, 2016}}</ref> The Wolf Law Building is located in [[Boulder, Colorado]], and is sited on the south side of the [[University of Colorado at Boulder]] campus. The law school houses the William A. Wise Law Library, which is a regional archive for federal government materials and is open to the public. [[United States Supreme Court]] Justice [[Wiley Blount Rutledge]] graduated from the University of Colorado Law School in 1922.<ref>[http://www.supremecourthistory.org/history-of-the-court/associate-justices/wiley-rutledge-1943-1949/ Wiley B. Rutledge, 1943-1949 « The Supreme Court Historical Society]</ref>
The University of Colorado Law School consistently ranks as a tier-1 [[law school]] in ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' rankings (ranked 46th as of 2018).<ref name="USNews2017" /> It is renowned for its influence in the 12-state Rocky Mountain region and for the strength of its [[environmental law]] program.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.colorado.edu/law/about-colorado-law | title = About Colorado Law | publisher = University of Colorado | access-date = June 3, 2016}}</ref> According to Colorado's official 2015 ABA-required disclosures, 74.2% of the Class of 2015 obtained full-time, long-term, JD-required employment nine months after graduation.<ref name="ABA2015">{{cite web | url = https://www.colorado.edu/law/sites/default/files/Class%20of%202015%20ABA%20Employment%20Summary.pdf | title = Employment Summary for 2015 Graduates | publisher = University of Colorado | date = April 7, 2016 | format = PDF | access-date = June 3, 2016}}</ref> For 2015 graduates, the overall employment rate was 96% at 10 months after graduation, including JD-required, JD-advantaged, and other positions.<ref name="ColoradoJobs">{{cite web | url = http://www.colorado.edu/law/careers/graduates | title = CU Law Graduate Employment Data | publisher = University of Colorado | date = April 7, 2016 | format = PDF | access-date = June 3, 2016}}</ref>
== History == Established in 1892, the University of Colorado Law School is a charter member in the [[Association of American Law Schools]] and appeared in 1923 on [[American Bar Association]]'s first ever publication of approved law schools. Although always located on the greater Boulder campus, the law school has occupied five buildings since its founding. For the first two years of its existence, the school was housed in the Kent building. From 1894 to 1909 the school occupied the Hale Law Building. For the next 50 years, until 1959, the school occupied the Guggenheim Law Building. From 1959 to 2005, the law school occupied the Fleming Law Building. In the fall of 2006, the law school once again moved and now sits in the Wolf Law Building.
== The Wolf Law Building == By the late 1990s, Colorado Law had outgrown its building. In 1997 law students voted to tax themselves with a $1,000 per year tuition differential to help finance the building, but in 2001 the State of Colorado General Assembly rescinded its earmarked funds from the project.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_4303562 | title = CU Students Pay for State Stinginess | last = Spencer | first = Jim | newspaper = The Denver Post | date = September 8, 2006 | access-date = June 3, 2016}}</ref> Facing the risk of accreditation loss, law students worked with campus leaders and successfully passed a $400 per year fee on all Boulder students to fund capital construction on the Wolf Law Building and three other campus projects.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.nationalbar.org/news/releases/release090806.shtml?AID=/20060817/UPDATE/608170449 | title = CU Making History in Legal Education | last = Davis | first = Marthea | publisher = National Bar Association | dead-url = yes | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110928060008/http://www.nationalbar.org/news/releases/release090806.shtml?AID=%2F20060817%2FUPDATE%2F608170449 | archive-date = September 28, 2011 | access-date = June 3, 2016 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> The Wolf Law Building was dedicated on September 8, 2006, by [[United States Supreme Court]] justice [[Stephen Breyer]]. The dedication ceremony represented the end of a long and creative funding process for a public law school.
In addition to student funds, over $13 million in private gifts were donated to support the construction of the new law building. The Wolf family, in honor of Leon and Dora Wolf, were especially generous in their contribution to the new building that now bears their family name.
The Wolf Law Building was constructed under the United States Green Building Council's LEED certification rating system for environmental sustainability and received a Gold rating.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.usgbc.org/projects/wolf-law-building | title = Wolf Law Building | publisher = United States Green Building Council | access-date = June 3, 2016}}</ref> Colorado Law is the second law school to be housed in a certified LEED building.<ref>http://www.colorado.edu/law/about/wolf-law-building/leed-certified-building</ref> In 2014, the Wolf Law Building was named the 9th Most Impressive Law School Building in the World by Best Choice Schools.<!--Is this relevant?--><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.bestchoiceschools.com/50-most-impressive-law-school-buildings-in-the-world/ | title = The 50 Most Impressive Law School Buildings in the World | publisher = Best Choice Schools | access-date = June 3, 2016}}</ref>
== Admissions == Admission to the law school is highly competitive. The school received 3,175 applications for the class of 2014 and matriculated 163 students. The 25th and 75th percentile LSAT scores for entering students are 160 and 165, respectively; the median LSAT is 164. The 25th and 75th percentile GPA for entering students are 3.41 and 3.79, with a median of 3.64.<ref>http://www.colorado.edu/law/details/</ref>
==Employment== According to Colorado's official 2015 ABA-required disclosures, 74.2% of the Class of 2015 obtained full-time, long-term, JD-required employment nine months after graduation.<ref name="ABA2015" /> Colorado's Law School Transparency under-employment score is 8.8%, indicating the percentage of the Class of 2015 unemployed, pursuing an additional degree, or working in a non-professional, short-term, or part-time job nine months after graduation.<ref name="LST2015">{{cite web|url=http://www.lstscorereports.com/schools/colorado/2015/ |title=University of Colorado Profile | publisher = Law School Transparency | access-date = June 3, 2016}}</ref>
==Costs== The total cost of attendance (indicating the cost of tuition, fees, and living expenses) at Colorado for the 2013-2014 academic year is $51,110 for residents and $58,620 for nonresidents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.colorado.edu/law/admissions/tuition-residency |title=Tuition and Expenses}}</ref> The Law School Transparency estimated debt-financed cost of attendance for three years is $197,814 for residents and $219,168 for nonresidents.<ref name="LST2015" />
===Controversial 2009 employment statistics=== In October 2009, the journal ''[[Law Week Colorado]]'' stirred controversy when it reported that only 35% of the school's Class of 2009 had jobs at graduation.<ref>Ashby Jones (10/22/09) [https://blogs.wsj.com/law/2009/10/22/absolutely-wretched-one-profs-take-on-legal-ed-in-the-down-market Absolutely Wretched’: One Prof’s Take on the State of Legal Ed] Wall Street Journal. Retrieved 9-30-10.</ref><ref name="abajournal">Debra Cassens Weiss (10/28/09) [http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/placement_office_scrambles_at_law_school_where_65_of_grads_had_no_jobs Law School Says Stats on Jobless Grads Were Wrong; Publication Differs] ABA Law Journal. Retrieved 9-30-10.</ref>
Officials from the school assailed the Law Week Colorado article. Former Assistant Dean of the Office of Career Development SuSaNi Harris called Law Week Colorado's report the product of a "miscalculation" and "misunderstanding" and claimed Law Week Colorado "confused 'employed' and 'unemployed.'"<ref name="abajournal"/> Later, Associate Dean Dayna Matthew told Law Week Colorado that the numbers released were "premature" and asserted that the National Association of Legal Professionals (NALP) would release more favorable statistics in February 2010.<ref name="abajournal"/> The reason, Matthew said, was that the NALP discounted graduates who did not report their employment status.<ref name="abajournal"/>
For its part, Law Week Colorado stuck to its original statistics and noted that the University of Colorado had not provided any new statistics.<ref name="abajournal"/>
== Ranking == In 2008, ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' ranked the University of Colorado Law School 32nd in the nation. In 2010, its ranking fell to 38th. In 2011, the school dropped to 47th, leading ''The Wall Street Journal'' to call the school "among the biggest fallers among the top 50".<ref name="WSJ2011">{{cite web | url = https://blogs.wsj.com/law/2011/03/15/the-2012-u-s-news-rankings-horns-hook-into-the-top-14/ | title = The 2012 U.S. News Rankings: Horns Hook into the Top 14 | last = Jones | first = Ashby | date = March 15, 2011 | publisher = ''The Wall Street Journal'' | access-date = June 3, 2016}}</ref> The school ranks 36th as of 2016.<ref name="USNews2017" />

{{multiple issues| {{Cleanup-rewrite|date=May 2009}} {{globalize/US|date=December 2010}} }}
'''Witness tampering''' is the act of attempting to alter or prevent the testimony of witnesses within [[Criminal proceedings|criminal]] or [[Civil procedure in the United States|civil]] proceedings. Laws regarding witness tampering also apply to proceedings before the [[United States Congress|U.S. Congress]], executive departments, and administrative agencies. To be charged with witness tampering in the United States, the attempt to alter or prevent testimony is sufficient. There is no requirement that the intended [[obstruction of justice]] be completed.<ref>{{cite web|title=1729. Protection of Government Processes—Tampering with Victims, Witnesses, or Informants—18 U.S.C. § 1512|url=http://www.justice.gov/usao/eousa/foia_reading_room/usam/title9/crm01729.htm|publisher=Justice.gov|accessdate=7 February 2014}}</ref>
In situations where '''intimidation''' or retaliation against witnesses is likely (such as cases involving [[organized crime]]), witnesses may be placed in [[witness protection]] to prevent suspects or their colleagues from intimidating or harming them.
In the [[United Kingdom]], witness intimidation is covered by [[Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994]], section 51. Under this act it is an offence to perform an act which is intended to and does intimidate a person who the offender knows or believes to be involved with a criminal case with the intention of disturbing the proceedings.
==United States== In the United States, the crime of witness tampering in federal cases is defined by statute at {{UnitedStatesCode|18|1512}}, which defines it as "tampering with a witness, victim, or an informant." The punishment for such an offense is up to 20 years if physical force was used, attempted, or threatened. The tampering need not have actually been successful in order for it to be criminal.
One of the better known cases involving Section 1512 is ''[[Arthur Andersen LLP v. United States]]'', decided by the [[U.S. Supreme Court]] in May 2005. The Supreme Court ruled that Section 1512 had been misinterpreted by the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit|Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals]], and reversed the decision of the lower court which had found the firm guilty of violating the section. The issue had, to some extent, become [[Mootness|moot]], because in 2002 the firm had all but dissolved as a result of prosecution on this criminal charge.
Examples of witness tampering include American politicians [[Buddy Cianci]], [[Meg Scott Phipps]] and [[Ted Klaudt]], convicted in 2001, 2003 and 2007, respectively.
==England and Wales== In England and Wales, witness intimidation by unlawful means, such as violence, bribery, threats, or improper pressure, is known as [[Perverting the course of justice]].
Section 51 of the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1994/33/section/51/enacted|title=Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994|work=legislation.gov.uk}}</ref> includes the offences of intimidating a witness and taking revenge on a witness.
==Kosovo== {{main|Kosovo War crimes witness intimidation and murder}}
==By prosecutors== A current source of controversy is the lack of penalties for prosecutors who commit witness tampering or other forms of prosecutorial misconduct. In the United States, prosecutors have full [[Legal immunity|immunity]] from [[civil liability]] regardless of how egregious their actions may be. However, prosecutors do not have immunity from criminal proceedings and can be professionally censured, but studies demonstrate that this rarely happens.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Jones|first=Leigh|title=Prosecutorial Misconduct Is Rarely Punished, Says New Study |journal=The National Law Journal|date=October 5, 2010|url=http://www.law.com/jsp/article.jsp?id=1202472897418&slreturn=20140107134232}}</ref>
In March 2003, the U.S. Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals, ruled against a man named Shareef Cousin, who filed a lawsuit against New Orleans prosecutors after he was wrongfully convicted of the 1995 murder of Michael Gerardi. A number of examples of witness tampering during the trial were uncovered. In court, a friend of Cousin's was expected to testify for the prosecution that Cousin had confessed to him. Instead, he told jurors that he had been promised leniency in his own trial if he would falsely implicate Cousin for the murder. An eyewitness then testified that she saw Cousin commit the murder. Her original statement to police indicated that she had very poor vision and could not identify the killer. Her statements regarding her vision were not disclosed to the defense. Cousin also accused the state of illegally detaining many of his witnesses to prevent them from testifying in his defense.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/08/01/prosecutorial-misconduct-new-orleans-louisiana_n_3529891.html|title=The Untouchables: America's Misbehaving Prosecutors, And The System That Protects Them|work=The Huffington Post}}</ref>

{{no footnotes|date=May 2014}} The '''Worst Forms of Hazards faced by Children at Work''' is a provision in the [[Worst Forms of Child Labour Recommendation|Worst Forms of Child Labour Recommendation (No. 190)]] adopted by the [[International Labour Organization]] (ILO) in 1999. It sets out the framework for examining and assessing, "work which, by its nature or the circumstances in which it is carried out, is likely to harm the health, safety, or morals or children" ([[Worst Forms of Child Labour Convention|C182]], Article 3d).
This effort is an attempt to complement the earlier [[List of the worst forms of child labour (ILO convention)|list of worst forms of child labour]]. According to the ILO, "hazardous" child labour is the largest category of the "worst forms" of child labour. An estimated 115 million children, aged 5–17, work in dangerous conditions in sectors including agriculture, mining, construction, manufacturing, service industries and domestic service. It is found in both industrialised and developing countries. Kids can take on hazardous work at very early ages. The ILO estimates that some 22,000 children are killed at work every year worldwide. The numbers of those injured or made ill because of their work are not known.
== General guidelines ==
The ILO provides the following guidelines for work considered unsafe for children, such as:
* Involving [[toxicity|toxic]] chemicals or fumes, high-powered equipment or vehicles, cutting, pounding or blasting * Taking place underground, [[underwater|under water]], at heights, in isolation, at night or in direct sunlight * Involving long hours without [[break (work)|break]]s * Carrying heavy loads * In the presence of alcohol, drugs or crime * In the presence of dangerous animals or insects * Absent easy access to [[safe water]] or food * In jobs with high injury rates
== Examples ==
* [[Hurrying|Hauling wagons]] in underground [[mining]] * Contact with [[solvent]]s and [[glue]]s in the leather industry * Glassworks (potential [[Lead poisoning]]) * Gold-mining (potential [[Mercury poisoning]]) * Underwater jobs without protective equipment, such as a wetsuit or air supply, in the fishing industry * Agriculture (potential [[pesticide]] exposure) * Bearing heavy loads in the [[construction]] industry * Exposure to [[radioactive]] materials in the [[nuclear power]] plant
== See also ==
* [[Child labor|Child labour]] * [[Worst Forms of Child Labour Convention|Worst Forms of Child Labour Convention (Convention No. 182)]] * [[International Programme on the Elimination of Child Labour|International Programme on the Elimination of Child Labour (IPEC)]] * [[Time-Bound Programmes for the Eradication of the Worst forms of Child Labour]]
